newsitem.title: UK: Major says no Emu decision ahead of election.
newsitem.headline: Major says no Emu decision ahead of election.

text.p: Prime Minister John Major said on Tuesday his Government would not decide ahead of a general election whether Britain should join a single European currency.
"This remains unequivocally the position of the Government," Major said in Parliament in reply to a question from Labour leader Tony Blair.

Major also reaffirmed an assurance given earlier on Tuesday by deputy Prime Minister Michael Heseltine that the Conservatives would not budge from a wait-and-see attitude to Economic and Monetary Union during the election campaign.
Major must call a general election by May 22.

He said finance minister Kenneth Clarke would spell out in a statement that he had won assurances at a meeting of European Union ministers in Brussels on Monday that a proposed stability pact limiting EMU members' budget deficits would not apply to Britain.
"Our position is legally protected under the treaty but we do intend to ensure that the detailed regulations leave no room for ambiguity," Major said.
